user_review: Cheval is in the top 10 to 20 steak houses in North America. The massive grill is memorable. 1 time there i dined alone at the var. 1 time there was with 2 guys. 1 time was a table for about 18. All great. I loved it.  Whatever you want from the fabulous waiters they will take care of. Go Bruins!

I will start by pointing out the obvious: This place is expensive. Definitely not something for a casual or budget meal. Having said that: the food is awesome! I went to queue de cheval for a work dinner and I really enjoyed It.  We were a big group (about 20 people) and we ordered family style, including a couple giant family sized wine bottle. We tried the oysters, steamed lobster, crab legs, tomahawk steak, Brussel sprouts, the larges meatiest shrimp  and three different types of dessert. Everything  was excellent and the service was impeccable. My wine glass was always full and a server was there at all time to anticipate my needs the reason for the  star: all the water that they serve is Fiji water which comes in plastic bottles. As someone who is trying to reduce plastic usage, I cringed every time the waiter opened a new bottle to refill my water glass. I am sure Montreal has good water, why waste the extra plastic ?? Why not switch to glass bottles if so inclined? Overall a great place to eat, specially if someone else is paying.

It always felt like a weird place inside & outside. Now with the media revelations, you wonder what else remains concealed. Did they cut corners in terrible ways that I don't know? Maybe they didn't. My feelings: just don't do it. Or at least read more about this place on the world's largest search engine & then decide if you want to take the risk.

The two stars is essentially for the service. I was in a party of 12 and the best man booked this steakhouse, this best man has been to probably almost every great steakhouse in America, but this isn't the united states, this is in fact Canada, north america if you will. The drinks, if you are going to use a smaller sized martini glass, then fill my fucking drink to the rim where all the volume is you cheap son of a bitches. This made me very upset. The Apps, only speaking for the wedge here, because we opted for no apps, no oysters, nothing. The wedge was meh, a $16 dollar wedge should never be meh, it should be YEAH. Too many chives smashed into the blue cheese, and I like chives, but not like that, leave my wedge alone. The Sides, I love mushrooms so when I see Chef Mushrooms on a menu I get very excited, we ordered 3 orders of these at $20 a whack, it was the most disappointing thing I have ever ordered they were essentially tasteless mushrooms sliced in 6 pieces laid out flat on a plate, they were the size of a quarter, you read that right. They should be ashamed of themselves, if I were the chef, I would be angry. The meat, bone-in rib eye, big surprise I know. They march out your choice all on a platter pre cooked, hey look,  these are your steaks, awesome. I don't care for any of this, you know what I do care about, ordering a medium rare steak and having it cooked basically medium, which meant the ends were well.....well. Also I realize we are in Montreal, but I didn't see anywhere on the menu that stated they are putting Montreal seasoning all over my fucking steak. This was it for me, I'll just leave the rest of this cooked meat on my plate in view for the waiter to ask me how was my steak? Guess what, never happened, they were very attentive to refill your water though, still water out of a bottle at $4 a pop. We had 7. Desserts, you guessed it, we opted out. They were nice enough to include a 23% tip in the bill, along with something called TPS and TVQ which I'll assume is some sort of tax to help with your free healthcare, correct me if I'm wrong? Actually don't I don't want know..... Oh and lastly, if you're going to be offended by photos that aren't classy, stay away from the Toilet, wash room, bathroom, restroom whatever the canadians are calling it, I'll post of a photo as well, of the owner on the toilet... Oh you think I'm kidding?!?!!?

Probably one of the finest steak meals I have ever had.And I have been to Ruth Chris, HY'S, Gotham's, Carver's from Las Vegas,Toronto,Vancouver, Hawaii and this was one of the finest meals both from the stand point of service to the meal.Nicolas and his crew were very helpful and gave some tremendous recommendations that served us well.We had three types of steak that were sliced up into thin strips and shared amongst the four of us. We had the Australian Waygu, USDA strip loin and the Alberta filet.Soooo amazing and each cut was so flavourful and tender. Couldn't say that one was better than the other, they were all excellent.Sides were a good size but there was nothing left over!It was an pricey meal but when entertaining clients it was impressive from the care and attention the staff showed to our clients as well it was a spectacular meal.I highly recommend this place if you want a truly fine steak in Montreal.I will be back.

Service was excellent. My wife and I shared the porterhouse for two... honestly it was okay... we've had better steak elsewhere. The steak itself tasted really "gamey" for some reason. The sides were good. Might go back to try different cuts and write another review. I guess it's worth going if you've never been but don't have super high expectations. We got lured in because of the pics on their Instagram lol.

I am giving the 5 stars because the service was great!!!! Our waiter was superb and the wait staff was incredible! We had a great dinner and great laughs. The rooftop was sooooooo nice and the entire place was just beautiful. definitely some improvements are needed, the drinks were really horrible. The waiter asked to change them 20x but we refused. Steak was delicious and very different, sides were ehhhh so so. Overall, great dinner and great night with the friends.

The food is delicious and the ambiance is excellent. The reason I am giving a 3 stars is because they force you to buy bottle of water for a ridiculous price. I don't like to have my hand forced, hence my review

I've dined at the Queue several times but not in it's newest location and this being our 20'th anniversary we decided to give the new location a shot for dinner. I booked a week in advance and showed up on time for our reservation after forking over $15.00 for valet parking."Reservation for Edward R? we have no reservation for Edward R, did you get a call from us confirming? I see a Edward R here but no reservation attached".???????In all fairness they did find us a very nice table on the second floor in a smaller dining room away from the sensory overload and din of the main dining room and we were ushered there by one of the "long of leg, short of skirt" young attractive hostesses that populate the front desk.Right away you can't help but notice all the frantic movement going on around you, this is not classic seamless French service but rather steakhouse on Redbull as a quartet of servers,waiters and a suited Matre d' bustle around distractedly attending to two long tables of apparently very thirsty gentlemen having a night out.Then comes the "Presentation", the preview to dinner where the featured seafood,Steaks,Lamb and apps are presented and hard sold, we had already decided on the 30 day aged 32 ounce porterhouse for two so I signaled we had already made up our minds and off he went to sell another couple.Drinks next and after a claim that the standard Brut was unavailable by the glass a offer of a Rose with a slug of Cassis, a Figi still water and a generous bread basket.The apps of Big eye tuna and steak tatare were ample if in need of some bolder seasoning.The porterhouse arrived on its own cutting board with 2 halved grilled head of garlic, my side order of garlic mashed potatoes and sauteed asparagus {all 6 anorexic spears}. Sliced against the grain the cut displayed all the mouth watering sheen and char that comes with a fire grilled steak and it was exactly as ordered medium rare.First bite was as expected, tender with that little bit of crusty char and that all too familiar blue cheese funk but sadly little else...Where was the beef? where was that savory, tannic bite of a well aged steak? This porterhouse looked the part,felt the part,even smelt the part but where was the beef?...Maybe a little sea salt would help and help it did but  not nearly enough to justify this steak's cost. This sadly is no Luger or Wolfgang's quality meats.All the while the bustling and running through and fro continued but with 2 more players as the bartender and another junior waiter has joined the fray and a offer of dessert. A bowl of vanilla ice cream swimming in a double shot of espresso and a tall shot of Frangelico mixed in is pure genius and my creme brulee is not too shabby with it's fragile shell hiding a creamy smooth custard......aaand it's over,rather anti climatic and really not worth it at these prices, the star of the show failed to deliver, sides were at best just okay,service was frantic,venue was noisy and overdone bordering on gaudy and the constant upselling became tiresome. This is not the Queue de Cheval I remember so fondly and that saddens me as the Queue in it's newest iteration has become just another well orchestrated tourist trap.Oh... remember my reservation that was there but really not?. Well it included a order for a small pastry to be brought to our table to celebrate our 20'th anniversary.. Yeah that was lost also.Merci mon ami but never again.........

The steaks while pricey are delicious and aged amazingly. Each steak comes with a roasted garlic that is melt in your mouth good.  Combine that with one of the best Caesar salad I have ever had and it makes an amazing meal.  The wine list is extensive but a little pricey. I do wish there were more Pinot Noir or heavier body Reds.  What adds to the experience is the staff was phenomenal
Overpriced and overly dramatic for what it is.   Loud disco music and fine dining do not mix.Sad.  It used to be decent but not anymore.C'est la vie...

Over priced. This is what happened to me: we are party of 3 and came here for steak. We ordered our steak and asked the waiter to suggest something for appetizer. He said shrimp is good so we took the shrimp. The shrimp turned out to be a 132 dollar appetizer! This is so ridiculous. I will NEVER come here again. And advice for ppl who want to try it: never order something that's not on the menu. Ask for the price of their suggested food.

Where to start....As a woman, you are treated like an accoutrement, not a personWas grossly ill every time I ate their grotesquely overpriced steak, The last time, so was my host as well, for 3 daysThis restaurant is for jocks with an expense account, and poor misdirected tourists...Keep your money in your pocket and go elsewhere...$9 for a baked potato which costs 10 cents....plus tax and service....Give me a break!!! Too many awesome restaurants in Montreal to waste your money here...

Went for the wife's birthday  Fiji water on the house. Birthday cake on the house. Food was ok  from NYC and used to big numbers  but the numbers here were obnoxious. 4 TINY SLICES OF CARPACCIO AND A HAND FULL OF ARUGULA. 25$ GREEK SALAD 25$ ALSO OBNOXIOUS. ITS TOMATOES AND CUCUMBERS FOR GODS SAKE.  STEAK NOTHING TO WRITE HOME ABOUT Coming here for 17 years. Come on Pete  Get back in the game. We loved this place.  What happened? Will be back again but please. Tighten it up.

I read many of the other reviews here and I just don't get it, did we all eat at the same place?   I had been to their old location several times but this was the first time in their new building.   I remain...impressed.     However to start, it was a hockey night and we weren't going so we made it clear that we weren't in any hurry.   Started a bottle of wine and relaxed while they hurried the other tables.  Was there with a colleague and we split a 30 oz bone in porterhouse.   I found the steak to be phenomenal, ordered it medium rare and that's how we got it.   I found the rub excellent.  Ordered mac and cheese and mushrooms for sides and these did not disappoint.   However, we did skip the apps knowing what we were in for.  Didn't do dessert because we were stuffed.   The service was attentive and appropriate.   Overall, I will be back and I'm looking forward to it.   Now there are some downsides, the wine list is limited and overpriced (but I've found the same in most restaurants in Quebec), it was expensive but no more so than Hy's, Morton's, or Capital Grill.  Great place for a special night or if you just want to splurge a little.   I will be back.

Heard so much about this place...the steak was good but this place is way over priced. 2 glasses of wine...they were small. Rib eye steakSalmon tartare (starter)Caesar salad$200 bucks I was never offered water.
Lambros was our waiter classy and took care of us as if he was one of his own. Great food and the dessert was phenomenal. Highly recommend.

The food was relatively good and the waiters were excellent. The experience, however, was tainted by watching the owner abuse and yell at the kitchen staff. He was slamming plates, swearing and plainly abusing his employees. It was one of the most pathetic displays of blatant abuse by a small and wretched man that I have ever seen. It left a horrible taste in my mouth and spoiled the hard work of the employees.

ATMOSPHERE: It's a very fancily decorated place. A little bit small but still lovely on the inside. Most walls have nice paintings on them, giving them a bit of that classic "antique" feel.FOOD: Overall, the presentation was very nice. The food itself was good. The steaks are tender and the fish has pretty good flavor to it. Unfortunately, for the price I paid, nothing really made me fall out of my chair but it was still quite tasty. It was a nice experience to have but I don't think I'd come back here again (for my wallet's sake and there are better things to eat out there).PRICE: It's definitely quite expensive. You'd only come here on special occasions, or if you're fancy enough, a business lunch. SERVICE: Service was pretty good. I expected much better from a high-end restaurant if I'm being completely honest.

To start with the conclusion, definitely come here if you want to try very exotic, expensive, amazing steaks (and they have all the normal top-flight steakhouse options too). It's not very often to see a menu with such a variety of extremely premium cuts, so steak lovers, prepare yourselves.I went with the Japanese A5 Wagyu 8oz rib cut. As you would expect, it was melt in your mouth delicious. A bit of nutty flavor from the dry aging added to the amaze-factor. Only a few things kept me from almost not going to a 5 Star on the review, one of them being my steak arrived a bit cooled down, probably because my fellow diners ordered cuts that needed more cook time, so I had a feeling it probably rested longer than usual.Our group had a fresh seafood tower, poutine (amazing!!), lobster mac'n cheese, creamed spinach, mushrooms, etc. everything was delicious.I'd like to thank the staff for doing their best to accommodate our group. We decided to sit outside (it was a bit cool, so they didn't have it open or staffed), but they teamed up and made us comfortable. Had they been fully staffed, I'm sure things would've progressed a bit faster. But I certainly won't ding the review because everyone was very nice and helpful while also covering their inside tables. The ambiance inside looked nice, but we had a lot of fun outside. And we were a bit loud anyway, so it worked out for everyone. I can't wait to visit again.

Terrible service and poorly prepared steaks. We waited 2 hours for the food to be served and was cold when it arrived. After my friend's steak was sent back twice, it was still raw and he couldn't even eat it. The waiter even spilled a bloody steak on my buddy. After the cold food and slow service, the only thing they would do for us was take the unacceptable steak off the bill and not charge us for a side of potatoes that they never even served. Unacceptable

The reviews here are a bit negative but I went with an open mind. In my humble opinion, I think most people end up deceive because they had really high expectations and it comes with a really hefty price tag. We had the tuna tartar as an appetizer. I really enjoyed it, especially the "spicy" sauce. So I will definitely recommend it. Then we shared a nice steak (20 oz Lou's cut: bone-in-rib) And drunken beef which is a 8 oz of filet mignon marinated in Porto topped with goat cheese. If you don't like goat cheese do not order this plate. The steaks were good but not the best I have I have ever had. {insert Drake verse} We ordered our steaks medium rare and they were closer to medium. We had a side of lobster mash. I think I would have appreciated it more if the pieces of lobster were bigger. Everything was ok/good but I didn't fell off my chair. We didn't have desert because we were pretty full. I really appreciated the service though. I'm not sure I will be back but I'm happy I tried at least once.

We were recommended this restaurant by the Sheraton. Food is expensive but totally mediocre. Ordered the dumplings which were hard and flavorless.  The food had no seasoning. The rib and jumbo shrimp had no flavor either.Would not recommend anyone to dine here, very disappointing.

Went here with 12 guys. Service was outstanding. Food was very good and fresh. Lots of people talk about the big number. Everyone had at least 2 alcoholic drinks, 6 appetizers, 3 seafood platters (which fed a nice amount to the 8 seafood eaters at the table) 6 huge steaks sliced up for the table. Everyone was quite full. $2300 CAD (($1760 USD included tip). From NYC so the number wasn't big to us.

Before coming I read many of the negative and positive reviews. Decided to try it anyway since it was close to our hotel and it was -11C with windchill. The short story: in my opinion, the nay sayers were wrong. Service was outstanding. They did NOT charge for the Fiji water at all - I checked the bill. The glass of wine they picked for me was $18 and a very reasonable Cabarnet Sauvignon.  The 60 day dry aged steak had to be cooked one degree more rare (I usually order it medium rare, and was advised by our waiter Johnny, when I asked  about this;  he told me the dry aging removes most of the blood and to order it rare). He was bang on the money on this one - outstanding steak - nice aged flavour, which is not for everyone. My wife's miso cod was sent back to the kitchen by the MANAGER because he did not like it's look and redone - my wife ate all of it - delicious. The only thing we didn't like was the lobster dumplings because it was way too spicy - when we asked about it - we were told that we could ask them to remove the Thai chili oil next time. Having eaten at more than 40 Las Vegas restaurants (many top end ones), I thought this held it's own. Not cheap folks, but quality seldom is. Put it this way, better than the steak I had at the famed Hawksmoor restaurant on Air St. in London (Piccadilly) where I was a week ago. Will definitely be back. Admittedly, I can afford their prices. Love other steak houses at Moishes, and Gibby's in Montreal, which probably offer better perceived value, but this was excellent nevertheless in my opinion.

Over the years  I have been there several times. The old place was simply amazing to look at and the food and service were the very best.   Something has been lost here about the old place. The magic of a wonderful dining experience is gone.      It was actually a really  enjoyable and memorable place to go to nearly 20 years ago.   Now it seems like it has lost its soul.  Frankly it now  feels all about money and all about trying to squeeze you for every penny.   I am not pleased with my recent visit.       In the past I did not mind paying such inflated prices because I am an infrequent visitor to Montreal and my trips to this establishment were kind of like a personal treat.  Well I am sad to say that the treat part is no longer in existence.   I will need to look elsewhere to be pampered and have a stress free and excellent dining experience that I used to find here.  It is GONE.    As many of the other reviews have stated here on Yelp the feeling is a common one that this place is very over priced and it seems that more and more of the members here feel that the food quality and service has gone down hill from what it used to be.     I am sad to be reporting this news as it means that one more good memory from the past days has left and is no longer with us.I note that many of the reviews here are making the same comment that they liked the place better in the old location and that the experience is no longer what it was or worth the crazy prices they are charging.I have decided to take the high road here and I have removed much of what I originally had to say because I believe it is better to save my energy for giving praise to a place that gave me a good experience rather than trashing a place that really offended me and disappointed me.     I hope that my comments here will encourage the ownership to step up their game, stop taking people for granted and try and restore the old level of service and quality to which their reputation was built.

WOW! We just arrived from one of the best meals any of us had ever had at a Steakhouse. I think that many of the negative reviews are left because of its high prices but when the food quality is that excellent, one must expect those high prices. Our server, Lambros, and the rest of the team really took our meal to the next level. To start, I had the Italian filet mignon tartar made with black truffle oil and Parmesan cheese (amazing with a slice of black truffle on top). We ordered 2 20oz Kobe steaks and a lobster tail for our table of 6. These were so wonderful and impressive that even the cooks were taking pictures of the steaks they had just cooked up for us. Every one of the sides we ordered were awesome, in order of my most favorite: Brussel sprouts, corn, creamed spinach, mashed potatoes. He also recommended a wonderful wine bottle that complemented our meal impeccably and especially the cheesecake dessert (unbelievably good!!). We're really hoping to make it back tomorrow before going back home. This might just be our new Montreal favorite.

Had a really nice time at La Queue de Cheval Steakhouse with my group of 7 people. As we arrived they took care of our coats and we were seated. The quality of service was perfect. We all ordered from their lunch menu, which is very affordable for the quality of service and food they serve (27$). I had their lobster bisque, traditional tartare with fries and their crème brûlée, everything was a-ma-zing. One person did complain about their food being greasy, she had an Italian tartare and didn't finish it. As a drink I had a half pint of beer which was also very affordable (6$). The plus of this visit was that we were taken for a tour of the restaurant, which is always interesting to me. I would definitely recommend this place for lunch for numerous reason, the top quality of their service, the quality of the product served, the particular attention they pay to their customers.

Decor is great and staff is attentive.  We had a business dinner here and came away with mixed results.  First course of oysters were delicious, paired that with a cocktail.  Their bar is not very well stocked.Steaks are large and properly cut, menu is varied.  I had a taste of lobster and it was cooked properly.  My steak and two shrimps were okay, but not great.  Shrimp well over seasoned, steak well underseasoned.  Asked for medium rare, got medium but the edges were carbon.They charge too much for their drinks for such a lackluster bar.  They make up for it in part for the variety of steaks, cuts, and origins.  Only in part, a steak restaurant should have those down to perfection and they missed it.

Way under rated here! Must come if you're serious about a good piece of meat!  We had the wagyu beef, was cooked perfectly! The service was very good, maybe some people have had bad experience but we went after the game at centre bell, it was perfect.

I love to give amazing reviews as we are foodies.  But tonight was a bust.Ate dinner at the bar.....the bartender would not leave us alone for any alone time.Pushing the most expensive dishes, describing them to be out of this world.Which we ended up taking his advise and was sorely disappointed.Not to mention the very expensive age steak was not cooked as ordered and way over done and dry( not moist/mouth watering). Also he messed up on our order which was pretty straight forward so had to wait for what we actually ordered.This caliber of restaurant you would think it would be top notch. Everything we ordered other than the scotch was totally mediocre or bland.Mediocre for a restaurant of this caliber is one that I will never recommend nor want to give patronage again.

Should have heeded the warning signs of hugely mixed reviews.My first night in Montreal, felt like steak, this place was a 2 min walk... ok, I'll risk it.  How bad can it be?Answer: really quite bad.It's a steak place... that is out of the first three steak options I pick.  Turns out when I ask that they only have two choices actually available (wtf?) - this is at 7 p.m., not some late night oddity.  OK, fine - at least they're not both the most expensive menu items.  Order a steak and a side of brussels sprouts.  The staff are reasonably friendly but uniformly supercilious, nothing hugely negative but again weird - do I look as though I need to have it explained that beef comes from a cow?Would have been enjoyable to have a glass of wine, but here I could not bring myself to spend  more than $20 for a glass of red from a bottle that retails for less than that; that described almost all the choices.  How about beer?  Well, "we have Coors light, or I could get you Newcastle in a bottle?"I drank water.Key question: is the steak good?  Nope.  It's clearly dry aged, has the funk, but not the tenderness nor flavour.  Cooked approximately as ordered (medium rare) although literally charred on one end and raw towards the other; stringy.  That was one unhappy cow.  Sprouts are watery and under-roasted (they'd clearly been parboiled and left to sit).  If this sounds pretty negative, well, it is: this is not a cheap place, and it's not worth your time or money.  Even the bread was stale.Hoping for better on my remaining evenings here..

Incorrectly cooked meat, ruined shirt, and slow service led to a disappointing dinner party.  No compassion or admission of mistakes from management led me to write this review.  The Hostess indicated we were late after arriving on time which confused us. Service:Drinks were ordered and several request for bread were left unfulfilled.  The food service was extremely slow and took almost an hour to bring out.  The kitchen staff brought the steaks out and reached over one of us and spilled the juices all over his shirt.  Most of the steaks were served warm or well done.  My steak was raw and only seared on the outside even though I ordered it medium.  Three of the side dishes we ordered were not delivered and we were asked "if we still wanted them".  The maître d' insisted they re-cook my raw steak [twice] and still failed to properly cook it to my desired temperature.Management Effort:Management was very defensive when we confronted them about the service and issues we had.  They did not offer reimbursement of our friends shirt, we had to remind them and only then did they agree they would pay for it.  No concessions were made when it came to the bill other than my undercooked, twice re-heated disastrous steak.  Half of our table did not eat their main course because of the lack of proper temperature.  Management stated that they saw each and every one of us (other than myself) finish their meals which was not true at all.Conclusion:As a high end steakhouse we expected a lot more.  Quality food prepared and served properly would have been a great evening.  Unfortunately a string of mistakes and no acceptance of poor service and quality from management led to an unhappy bachelor and disappointed friends and family.

My husband brought me to this place because the French restaurant that we have been going in the past 3 years, The Fairmount Elizabwth Hotel Beaver Club, for my birthday, was under renovation (our yearly tradition).Food was ok, more Montrealers' standards, there are many other options for tasting steak and seafood. we ordered a fresh sea urchin sitting on the ice hill at the seafood counter area. I wanted it because i always take sea urchin sashimi style at japanese restaurants. We were disappointed about this dish since there were loads of seaweed inside the shell, interwined between the meat, making it hard to eat, taste it on my tongue  and swallow it because I had to remove the seaweed at every single bite. No way, this was completely not what I used to like from Japanese cuisine. We wasted $29.00 + tax for this little creature!!! Other dishes included rack of lamb grilled on charcoal, prime rib steak au jus, grilled jumbo tiger shrimps with thai style sauce. I had a glass of white wine from the limited by-the-glass selection list. At the end, We expected an expensive bill because of its reputation: $360.We were not at all astonished and satisfied with the food. Don't think we will come  back again.

Went to this place on Monday. Had high expectations, as I heard it was a really good steakhouse. I was in for a business trip so the people I was visiting took 6 of us to the restaurant. We had a very nice server who explained everything to us. The majority of us ordered medium rare, one of us ordered medium well. Every single one of our steaks were cooked wrong. The three of us that ordered medium rare got steaks that were rare..... and the one who ordered medium well got well done. One of us ordered lobster and it was overdone too.The quality of the meat was really good, but the chefs need to learn to cook steaks. One of my coworkers spoke to the manager and he looked like he was telling us to get out and F off with his eyes. We were just giving honest feedback.To top it off, after we left we noticed they charged us for an extra bottle of wine.NEVER RETURNING HERE

Alright, so!1) The food. OMG, how is that even possible to burn a steak in a steakhouse! Even mashed potatoes were not really properly mashed. I ordered cognac and lemon, well, yes, I saw the peace of lemon being taken by hand, without using a napkin but at least on a plate. For the fact in Jack Astor's once they brought me lemon in hand!!2) Not clean bathroom for sure.3) Service. Pushy and sneaky!It is definitely not michelin star restaurant but good looking one if you come to impress someone not with food.Overall. Overpriced and not delicious for sure!
If you are a desert lover you cannot pass aside of their amazing White Chocolate Cheesecake!!'Its to d

Amazing place Best experience so far , they have the best wine and an amazing variety of excellent heavenly starters , I could only be satisfied with the starters for they were extremely good , they seem to use the best ingredients and the best flavors , they have the best steaks and sea food in Montreal , a place not to miss when in town , they have a huge bar downstairs with a big variety of sea food and another place upstairs , the dishes were coming out of an open kitchen where you could see the chefs preparing the food with the best high quality ingredients and the best presentation , considering that they have the best steaks and sea food in town they are not as pricey as we thought , we tried the steak and halibut and as entrees the Aliki salad ( Greek salad) and the tartare of tuna and salmon and everything was amazing and out of this world ! A gem place in Montreal!

Between the dead grey "medium" steak, under-seasoned fish, hand towel with a stench, and the pushy server who's trying to get you order twice than needed, I don't know why people eat here, so many lovely restos everywhere in the city. The bread is good.

Ok so here is the thing.  If you appreciate a quality dry-aged steak, all that goes with it, and a proper fine dining experience, you wont do any better in this city.Spoiler alert: this is not cheapDropped in with my buddy on Saturday and ate at the bar.  We were greeted by Danny and Gabrielle, the latter as lovely as the former is wise.  We started with a couple drinks and were soon joined by the owner, Peter, who took 15 minutes to sit and talk with us about steaks, women, life, and how i look more Greek than my friend, who is Greek.He even bought us our next round.(I don't think he does this often, so thanks again Peter!)Apparently Peter yells at his staff.  After talking with him i know it is because he cares about details.  He is as selective about his staff as he is his steaks.  If his customer isnt having the right experience, he lets his staff know.  I personally wish more restaurant owners cared this much.I read the word "pushy" in a few reviews here.  They are a business and they are enthusiastic about their product.  Danny and the others put in some effort to move the product.  The ones i wanted, i bought.  Those i didn't, i didn't.  He did this between discussions about his carnival days(seriously), american politics, curling, and even the premature passing of his father.  I also learned more than i ever thought possible about RWA beef!This place has an identity.  So do its products and its staff.  Danny, Gabrielle, Peter (and his reticent son) and even Majeed(!) made our evening. If you understand fine dining and appreciate the cost associate with such an experience, they will knock your socks off. If you just want a decent steak and a baked potato, there are plenty of those options around town as well.

This place has gone downhill since it's original location. Went for a Sunday evening meal, based on a positive experience at their old restaurant, and it was mind blowing how bad it was:(1) For 'the best' steak in Montreal, it is average at best, at a very high price. (2) the wait staff are extremely invasive, our waiter was listening to our conversation all evening and would periodically jump into our conversation when he heard something that interested him. (3) The manager came to ask how our steak was when we started the meal. We told him average, it was chewy. Instead of correcting it, he just walked away. (4) after we ate our meal, the waiter cleared the table and asked how our food was. We said (again) average, it was chewy. The waiter responded "well it sure looks like you enjoyed it" (because the plate was almost clear). We said "it was average, not bad. For the price, it should have been excellent". (5) we ordered one steak to share between two people, based on the ounces we wanted (20 divided by 2 people). The waiter decided on his own to increase it to 30, without us knowing. The price was double ($130 in total). When we asked about it when the bill came, they did not correct it. So basically, we paid double the expected price (about $450 for 3 people + a vegetarian) for average steak and extremely rude wait staff. Montreal is known for its food scene, go to any other place, Joe Beef, Liverpool house, Maison Publique, etc etc etc and honestly, even the Keg!
Fabulous service and an exquisite meal. Difficult to find a better steak house anywhere.

Went there for a business dinner before the hockey game.  Friendly front of house and a great waiter who recommends the prime rib (only two left).  My colleague and I both ordered that and a couple sides.  Food came out pretty quickly.  Steak was well prepared, average for a high end steak house, but in my opinion not worth the expense.Downfall of the restaurant and the night: the chef who was expediting.  During the meal the chef is loudly and profanely berating one of the line cooks for an improper preparation.  This carries on for quite some time, dies down and then comes back again.  The chef repeatedly calls him an f-n moron and an idiot.  The line cook replies, mistakenly, that he was preparing the food as the chef wanted which prompted the response "I AM THE F-N CHEF!".  If the line cook doesn't know who the chef is then you've got management issues.  Additionally, this is an open kitchen so the whole restaurant heard this as it continued on.  Unfortunately we were sitting close to the kitchen.I don't understand this kind of behavior and it ruined a business meal, an expensive meal, and a new restaurant to me.  I will not be going back nor taking any clients there.

One of the Montreal's most well known steakhouses became the site of our most epic dinner during my friend's bachelor party weekend. In the midst of planning for the dinner, there was a tossup decision between this place and cross town rival Gibby's (yelp.ca/biz/gibbys-resta…). The deliberation ended with Queue de Cheval for one thing: amazing service. From the phone reservation to greeting us at the door to the end of the meal, they did one heck of a job in accommodating our party of 12 hungry men.From the outside into the lobby, it's easy to see how beautiful this restaurant really is. In true steakhouse fashion, there are various cuts of meat from all parts of the world on display, something a true meat connoisseur can surely appreciate. We were able to get a spot on the second floor facing the street and the restaurant was like many other upscale steakhouses: trendy decor, well dressed patrons and wait staff, a lively ambiance just buzzing with activity. Generally speaking, the food always takes precedence in any restaurant but in places like this, service is of the utmost importance. The wait staff was quick and handled everything with ease, we almost never had to ask for anything as water was filled quickly, bread was refilled automatically, and there was never any attitude. Our main waiter was sharp, humorous, and extremely knowledgeable about virtually every item on the menu and was able to make some killer recommendations for drinks and food. We decided to pass on their appetizers, a majority of which would sully our carnivorous appetite for the one thing we came for - steak. Almost all of us were sold on the 20oz Lou's Cut ($54), which is the place's most popular steak.Along with the steak we ordered multiple sides of creamed corn ($12), truffle and parmesan fries ($7), garlic mashed potatoes ($5), along with a heaping of steak sauces: veal and truffle reduction ($6), cognac peppercorn ($6), and a cabernet sauvignon demi glace ($6) and staring at us was a hell of a meal.Everything was fantastic. The creaminess of the garlic mash, coupled by the delicious sauteed garlic spinach was melt in your mouth good. There were multiple foodgasms galore over the Lou's Cut, a hearty Colorado imported hunk of steak heaven in it's medium rare glory, juicy and went great with everything. The steak sauces weren't even all that necessary, but once added, there was no going back. Every bite was enhanced, the flavors were so rich, it was just the perfect amount of food; life was suddenly perfect.   Along with the Australian red and whites we sipped throughout the night, including 4 orders every side and a Lou's cut, the price we paid (sans the bachelor of course) was a very reasonable $82 per person. The conversation was as excellent as the food which was stellar as the service. Steakhouses might feel a tad more expensive in Montreal, mainly due to the importing of all of the meat, but when in town, this is one of the best places for steak period.Here's a parting thought for everyone: yelp.ca/biz_photos/Ek4sV…

Six guys on a bachelor party rolled in on a Thursday night. We ended up spending more money than we were anticipating, but in the end it was all worth it. Originally we were going to have a normal sit down meal, but when we got our first couple rounds at the bar we just decided to eat there. The bar was excellent and the service was top notch. The 2 male bartenders were excellent with their conversation and stories. They had a beautiful new female bartender in training and she was great conversation as well. Steaks were excellent but they had a "head steak waiter" who was constantly just trying to push the most expensive cuts. The prices on the website menu were lower than the prices on the real menu, which was kind of off-putting but nothing to ruin a night. We also partook in some of their selections from the raw bar. Both east and west coast oysters were delicious. Overall, great time and would definitely recommend for a special occasion. Just be careful as the bill can skyrocket when you're having a great time!

I know it is too expansive and I don't like their starters much !!! Not worth it at all , however the meat I had was one of the best ones so far ! It was just melting in my mouth so tender !! Also I found the waitress super loud specially once in a summer time  when we were sitting outside he was talking to the valet out loud !!!!

Favourite place to eat at in Montreal!The staff is very well spoken and welcoming as well as knowledgeable about their menu, wine and bottle lists. Multiple times I have been served by a very kind yet funny gentleman, wish I got his name. He always made the experience that much better! Every meal I have had their has been delicious and never have there been mistakes in my orders or specific requests. The terrace was also very nice, secluded and private. The ambience of the whole restaurant is polished yet constantly active unlike other pricier restaurants in which I feel as though I sulk in the beige decor. From valet to coat check, everything is there! Love this place and think it is one of, if not the best steakhouse in Montreal!

Staff isn't welcoming. Every time you go there the look at you from head to toe with judgement. Took them more than an hour to cook medium rare steak, and it was not even good had to take Toms to feel better. Overrated, would not be coming back

This is a review for the Burger Counter at the back of the new building.It's probably the cheapest way to find out about the hype without spending a fortune.Still pricey, around $20 for a burger, fries and soft drink.I had the Mob Burger, Pepperoni, Mozzarella, spicy tomato sauce and Mushrooms.While I can tell that the ingredients are top notch, my burger tasted like pizza with some ground beef in the middle. It was not my first choice (they ran out of the MTL Burger Week Special), and was recommended by the staff.I went back the next day to see if they had the Special, they ran out. ---------------------------------------------Description below-----------------------------------------------(An incredibly delicious and unique cult burger consisting of fresh saffron hollandaise, a sunny side egg, sauteed wild mushrooms, sauteed Jumbo Bay Scallops (Butterfly), 3-4 oz medallion of Filet Mignon, bacon jam, confetti of red tobiko caviar with a drizzle of truffle oil all resting between 2 artisan bread buns, $14.99)I would go back and try whatever else burgers they have, but that QDC burger is a must, the guy said they might bring it back on the regular menu. Skip the fries, they are ok, but not sensational and not worth $3.50.Service is ok, they had just re-opened but already were strumming along.There's not much of a seating area and you're gonna be eating sitting on a bench in a parking lot. Best to eat it elsewhere.

My friends and I went to this restaurant, looking for a high end experience, and we were very disappointed.  We were expecting an experience like we receive at Del Friscos, or Capital Grille or Ruths Grill, but it was nothing even remotely close (even though it was ~50% more expensive than those restaurants). The attention to detail in the way the wait staff brought anything to the table (glassware, silverware, or food), was not the same as what you would expect from a high end steakhouse.  The waiters even spilled steak blood all over my friend's shirt because they were serving the food from above our heads. (and the manager did not want to compensate us for that until we sent him the dry cleaning receipt).The steaks did not come out warm and most of them were cooked incorrectly (even after having sent them back to the kitchen).My friends and I left most of our steaks untouched and were extremely disappointed. Do yourselves a favor and go to Gibbys instead.  Much better steakhouse and experience.

Queue de Cheval has been heralded as amongst the top steakhouses in Montreal - and i'm sorry to say - but this is far from true.I had an interesting experience at the restaurant - i got to see it at a few stress points. Namely the following: The restaurant was busy - seated right next to the open kitchen - the stress of being busy turned into chefs yelling at each other and swearing at each other which really didn't make for a pleasant experience.We got a bad steak - a companion got a bad steak, and so at the prices we were paying, we suggested she let the mgmt know. Their response was to get her a new steak and charge her for both. Appalling and cheap. The 'fresh' food - i didn't think much for the food. I had a 120z baseball filet. My filet was not even close to baseball shaped - it was more a flat sirloin. And the meat was not tender like a typical filet either. It felt like i had been served a sirloin but i didn't bother saying anything. Add to it, the steak was terribly burnt on the outside, with a sharp gas tasting char to it. And add to it, i ordered the U5 shrimp at the suggestion of the server, which came out with an apricot basil sauce of some sort - i wish i had been warned or informed of that prior because it was not good at all.Overall, i found the food bad, the service excellent, the ambience interesting but terrible thanks to the yelling chefs, and the management horrid.   At $280 per head, i would expect so much more. I left feeling like i had totally been ripped off the experience i was expecting. I will never go here and i suggest you don't either. If you're looking for a good steak in Montreal, go to Viex Port, Moishes or Joe Beef - but stay clear of this excuse of a restaurant.

Service is really good, they are even go check if they have sake for me cuz we ordered seafood platter. Sashimi are fresh, uni was little, king crab leg was too salty, shells are not bad, lobster n tiger shrimps taste good, steaks are not bad with little more spicy taste as they suggested but I think they gave me medium after I ordered medium rare:( There was too many people at hockey night so they took too long for my coffee(didn't count in my bill) and nothing remarkable with their desserts since I'm not a fan of chocolate.

Very expensive for not much of a result.......I just think if you're a steak house then you should be able to cook steak to order, not above or below, it's your job.......nuff said......imho It's ok, not great and the price is more than an ok.....

I've been really *not* looking forward to writing this review. I do not even know where to begin. Unless you're swiping your company card or coming here for a bachelor party, this place should be avoided. Long story short: This place has been coasting on its' reputation for so long that it has forgotten to focus on the most important thing: the people that come into your establishment. So, we had a show at the Bell Centre later in the evening. We came in immediately when the Lobster bar was supposed to open in order to make time for the show. First, upon arriving, we were made to wait since the owners or managers were downstairs and in a meeting. Not even offered a drink for the inconvenience, just told to wait. For over 20 minutes. After our reservation. Ok, that's fine - we'll take a look around. I dig some of the design elements, we checked out some of their events online, it's definitely a chauvinistic establishment full of pomp and arrogance. Doesn't reverberate with us, but we won't count that against them.We finally get downstairs and get seated. No prices on the menu. Ok. We explicitly asked about pricing and got the run around. Great. There's some people at the bar pounding drinks and swearing like sailors. Sweet. Bartender is audibly bitching about guests from the night before. Awesome. Manager yells at one of the bus boys. Amazing. After spending some time bragging about the importance and status of Queue de Cheval, our waiter finally took our order (but not after trying to up-sell the living shit out of us). I will say that he took some time to bring out cuts of meat and show us the value in the cuts offered by the restaurant. While it was a nice gesture, it was clear that the display was more of a rehearsed gimmick than a deliberate effort to answer our questions. We ordered the tasting menu and the food began to come out. While the presentation lacked inspiration, we were cautiously optimistic, since the two first courses were decent. Nothing mind-blowing, but decent (at the very least, not disappointing). First course: The shrimp in buerre blanc was pleasant; the bone marrow with brioche was well cooked, though underseasoned and the brioche's sweetness somewhat overpowered the flavour of the marrow. The gnocchi with braised meat and parm shavings was delicious, but extremely heavy after a few bites. Still, tasty.However, our cautious optimism was destroyed as soon as the main courses were brought out (a sampling of three cuts of differently aged meats). We were paying 200 bucks (after tax) just for food, and the cuts were completely overcooked, requiring you to literally chomp through the char to get to the dry, flat, hardened pucks of beef underneath. This is a fundamental fail for a place that prides itself on the quality of its meats. It was clear that the grill wasn't even properly prepared. The meat pieces were covered in an unidentifiable (slightly nauseating) layer grease of some sort - it felt a bit like they hadn't properly cleaned the grill, and had started cooking the meat while the grill was still heating, then left the meat to cook for too long. When desert came down, one of the components of the three-dessert sampler was just flat-out gross (though, to be fair, their chocolate lava cake was quite good). Long-story short, this place needs some TLC. Everything but certain elements of the decor and two or three elements of the meal was a let down. There is an overwhelmingly self-congratulatory air to this place - they clearly feel like they are doing the public a favor, and are excused from offering value in exchange for the (considerable) money spent in their establishment. We will never go back.
Incredible dry aged steaks, amazing service, an excellent wine list. This restaurant is exquisite and top notch. Highly recommended if you can afford it.

This was my first time in a steak house in Montreal and it didn't disappoint. Everything we ate was excellent. A wide selection of choices even if you don't eat steak. Staff was very friendly and knew a lot about the cuts of meat for the day. The place is decorated stunningly. I recommend the meatball as an appitizer and saving room for the cheesecake

Really disappointing....My wife and I visited this restaurant because we both wanted to treat ourselves to a nice steak and felt we couldn't go wrong at a "fancy" place.  This place tries to be a Capital Grille or Mortons but does not come close in my opinion.  My Beefeater had floating chunks of blue cheese in it from the poorly stuffed blue cheese olives and the waiter was extremely annoyed that I sent it back.  He seemed to have an attitude the entire time actually...The filet I ordered medium rare was a flavorless medium.  I had a MUCH better steak at Firegrill that day for a fraction of the price.  The steaks were also not fired on time, we waited an additional 20 minutes and would have assumed the manager would comp a round of drinks but never even came over.The poor guy in the red jacket who was running around trying to attend to everyone was seen getting scolded by the waiter in front of everyone which was embarrassing.  This place really is not worth the price.  We paid $200...What a mistake.

While in Montreal we stopped here to eat.  I was great! The service was Excellent. We had Kobe Steak with Lobster. Amazing! Cooked to Perfection. Loved the decor.  The wine that the server recommended was fabulous.  A must try!!!
A really uncomfortable experience. Highly unrecommended.

I had been to this place years ago.  And its just as expensive as I remember!!! I was not sure if I should give 3 or 4 stars!! My wife ordered the seafood platter as an opener!! It was big and so was the cost. This is how I described it, OK and expensive while when I think of Florida where its amazing and cheap!! My wife still liked it!! I ordered the Baseball cut fillet Mignon!! I wanted it med-rare. Have of it was but the other half was well done and dry!!! Strange!!!! It was good and I enjoyed my meal and the wine. Dessert was a white chocolate cheese cake which I had a small sample and it was great!!! I am easy going but the boss was swearing his head off at the staff and was freaking out some of the customers!! He should just be careful with the F words. Does not bother  me but it did others and this is a fancy restaurant!!! For this reason 3 stars instead of 4!!!
Amazing service and steak! Great aged meat.

We are visiting from Chicago and went on a recommendation from the hotel.  The service was outstanding.  I loved, loved the tuna tartare!! My fish entree was excellent-- my  husband's steak was wonderful.   I agree that it was pricy but I must applauded them on fabulous service.

Tourist trap. Overpriced for average food and service. This is not fine dining, it is a standard steakhouse trying to be by selling large shrimp and lobster. Wrote to the restaurant, owner went defensive and answered that since i wrote a review, addressing my concerns was futile, and since I was not happy, that I should have sent my plate back to the kitchen. But...hard to send everything back, especially when you share a steak. Old bread, and they charge you for water but do not tell you.

Before visiting Montreal I looked up a bunch of restaurants to go to and this was one of them. I looked at reviews and it was pretty much 50/50. Some good reviews along with some bad but it didn't matter because I had to see if Canada's steakhouse plays second fiddle to the U.S. as it does with so many different things.The setup of the restaurant is nice, two floors, an open grill, artwork throughout the restaurant, cigar lounge, the works. Bread- The customary bread basket was brought to the table. I sampled but was not impressed at all. I had to tell the waiter to remove it from the table because I did not want to ruin my appetite.Appetizers- There is a good selection of seafood and meat apps. The shrimp looked bigger than those at Prime 112 in Miami and that's saying alot. My friends and I decided to share the angry lobster and short rib dumplings which was something you would expect to see at a Chinese restaurant and not a steakhouse. Nevertheless it was delicious. The rib to lobster to dumpling ratio was on point. The sauce it was dipped complemented the dish very well. Steak- The restaurant imports the beef from Nebraska and Colorado. One is grass fed and the other corn fed in case you wanted to know the difference. I decided to go with the Lou's Cut 20 oz bone in rib-eye. My friend wanted to order the lamb but I made a save like Patrick Roy and told him to get steak, I should of gotten a Conn Smythe award for that save. We both ordered it medium. I don't like to give such high praise after only trying something once but it was one of the best steaks I've ever eaten. The steak was cooked perfectly, outside to inside. Pretty in pink throughout like Molly Ringwald. My other friend ordered the 18 oz bone-in-filet. I would say 12 oz of that was bone. It tasted good but it's very disappointing that so much of it was bone. In all fairness they did show us at our table the steaks that they would be cooking for us. We should have shut that down when we saw it.Sides- Wide variety of starches and vegetables. The mac and cheese is listed as an appetizer but true to the game it was ordered as a side along with the lobster mash potatoes. But ranked very high in terms of as good as it gets. The portions were sufficient for 3 people and it complemented the steaks very nicely. Desserts- The usual suspects are on the menu: molten cake, creme brulee, cheesecake, etc. The waiter brings out the dessert tray to give you an idea of what they look like. We were all pretty full so we decided to share the cheesecake which was covered with chocolate on top. It was very rich and heavy but tasted good. If I had 20 minutes to wait for the molten to bake or if the waiter gave us a heads up on the baking time it most likely would have been ordered.Overall, I give the Q 4.5 stars and that's only after 1 visit. Steak, sides, and cost rival many of the top steakhouses in the U.S.

I was in Montreal for a mate's bachelor party a few days ago and we chose this place over another highly rated steakhouse. In the end, it was one of the better decisions we made that weekend. First the positives: Absolutely enjoyed the ambiance and the staff. From our waiter making great recommendations on the cuts to Chris M., helping us plan our post-meal adventure and helping to settle a bet, the attention to detail was perfect.For my dinner, I had the baseball cut filet mignon, and it was prepared just as I requested it. I know how hard it can be to please this group of executives, but Queue de Cheval, did just that. The only gripe I can think of is the seafood. The lobsters and tiger shrimp came out overcooked. Yes, I'm being picky, but this is the only way a high-caliber restaurant like this one improves. On my next trip to Montreal, I will definitely be back.
Always a favorite when I come to town. This location is even better than the first time I ate here. So worth the splurge... best steak ever!

My husband and I were there Friday night and we were so disappointed. We sat downstairs in a very nice booth across the beautiful bar. The music was very good really put us in a celebrating mood. Then came the food and it was all downhill from there. His tuna tartar was very good my ceasar salad was terrible. Too much dressing and the lettuce was all the dark green outside leaves. Could not finish it for how bad it was. Then we both ordered the 20 ounce bone in rib eye medium rare. Waiter convinced me to season it with Montreal steak spice which I did not think a good steak would need but he insisted. They showed us 2 beautiful raw thick steak and said those were are steaks. Then when they came to our plate they looked totally different and were not thick anymore. They were over cooked more medium. When they asked us how it was we told them the truth and they tried to explain that the meat shrinks when it cooks. 20 ounce steak should still be thick after it cooks. Then the manager came and asked the same question we gave him the same answer. His solution was to bring us a piece of garlic butter to spread over it to give it more flavour. So their meat is so bad that it needs Montreal steak spice and garlic butter to try to make it taste good. Even then we could not eat our $55. Each steak. They did not compensate or apologize for any of it. The wine is overpriced. $20 for a glass of Chablis. Paid $55 for the bottle at la Societe. I guess our expectations were too high.

I like this restaurant but it's really expensive and heavy on staff. Has a wonderful atmosphere. My Loup de mare was perfection. The aged beef my family had was ok. Not my thing. Very nice waiters. A little fussy for my taste. Go but prepare to spend some money.

We made  an 8PM reservation 2 months ago with high expectations. When we sat down the waiter tried to upset us on everything.  He was very pushy with the expensive Kobe steaks.  They were out of 5 of the steaks on the menu including the aged Porterhouse.  I have never heard of a steakhouse being out of a porterhouse especially at 8PM on a Saturday evening. The quality of the steaks was very good but we unfortunately had to order whatever steaks that were in stock.  Some of the sides came late after we were finished with our entrees.  I would not return to this restaurant

Horrible experience, save your money. A $250 price tag for an appetizer, two glasses of wine and two steaks with a side dish in a terrible atmosphere and an absolutely appalling display from the servers. When we sat down (at not a great table, upon deciding we wanted to be moved we realized that the layout of this restaurant is so poor there actually is no good table) we could barely hear ourselves over the music blasting from the overhead speakers. Upon asking, they turned the music down, only to have them turn it back up again about 20 minutes later. There was some sort of conflict happening amongst the service staff, one waiter kept shouting expletives and the managers were shuttling back and forth trying to solve the dispute. The entire experience was unpleasant and stressful. Avoid at all costs.

So... I actually came here for the QDC burger and the restaurant for their steaks.  I didn't realize it was the same place till after I had dinner here.  Then it all made sense... QDC... Queue de Cheval.First the burger.  I tried the spicy shrimp burger.  I loved the char on the bread (I think it's like a Focaccia?) , it gives it a great smokey flavor but the bread was a little too substantial / thick.  Overwhelms the meat a little bit.  They pile on the spicy shrimp onto the burger.  The shrimps alone were awesome.  Piled on the burger, not so much. Also with the sauce from the shrimp, the burger was dripping .   i would have probably like the normal burger more.  Now for the dinner. lobster carpaccio was okay, it just needed a much better sauce.  The side dishes were okay, my favorite was the mash potatoes.  The duck fat fries were okay, a little chewy.  The steak was cooked well... good char on the outside.  Perfectly medium rare on the inside... but something was just off about it.  Lacked flavor, a little dry.  The waiter raved about the quality of the meat... but I just found it lacking.  Ambience is okay. For a nice steak house, I find the TVs distracting.  music is blasting like we're in a club.  Wish they were tone down some of that stuff.

The environment is cozy with nice bars. Food is not bad but doesn't meet the expectation. Manager is nice but the waiters are rude. Don't choose this restaurant if you expect authentic French cuisine.

I had been to the Queue de Cheval a couple of times several years ago when they were located on Rene-Levesque, and although I never ranked it among the best steak houses I've eaten at, it was always very good.This weekend, a group of friends and I tried it again (it is temporarily located inside the tacky nightclub, 1234 on de la Montagne) and I regret to say that it was one of the WORST meals I have had in a restaurant in a very long time.If I explained everything that went wrong, this review would be 15 paragraphs, so I'll keep it as short as possible: the meals came out at different times (the last person was literally served 30 minutes before the first), the food was not good (bland, overcooked steak, dry & tasteless lobster carpaccio), the service staff was not only disorganized but arrogant, and to top it all off, they seated us next to the nightclub entrance and opened the velour curtains at 10:00 pm, at which time we were freezing from the draft, annoyed by the cheezy eurotrash, and bothered by the scantily-clad 19 year old girls shoving their way into the club.The most unbelievable part of it all was when we complained to the manager. He called the owner to ask him what to do, and the owner who passed on the following message to our table: "I don't care if they didn't like it, tell them to never come eat here again."This restaurant is NO LONGER a top-tier steakhouse. What it is now is a hugely overpriced restaurant in a nightclub with sub-par food. Horrible.

Just to confirm all the less than stellar reviews here.  Far better places for much cheaper prices.  You'll need to ask for salt because they don't use any.  Service is a bit overbearing.  Layout of the restaurant means it's likely someone will bump into your chair a few times while dinning, usually the wait staff.  Don't get the twice cooked bake potato fries.  Also watch that they will try to sell you a more expensive bottle of wine, even if it's not as good.  (Since I'm from California wine country I happen to know).  They do not offer corkage, so don't bring your own bottle of wine.  Even the layer chocolate dessert was not very rich nor complex in flavors.  At these prices the bar is pretty high.  Very disappointed.

2 stars is a stretch for this place. It used to be soooo much better before!!! For 1, its overpriced- i dont mind paying for great food, but their food is sub par! Nothing nooothing was great. I hate that there are 7 tables and 20 waiters- hello!!! Some privacy please! Also, do they get regular beatings there?? You could cut the pressure with a knife there! I just could not relax and sit back. A supposedly romantic date night was almost ruined, we decided to go for desert to la societe- that saved the evening! All in all- dont go! Dont waste your money! Spend your $300 per couple at maison boulud or europea!
Overrated experience and awfully rude staff. Way better options to eat in Montreal, especially for that price range.

Queue de Cheval used to be one of the things that I loved about Montreal.I had been to the old location twice over the years and thought the food was average to good but that the atmosphere and decor made up for it. If I knew that they moved to a temporary location (for 6 months) I never would have gone.The food was as I remembered it, adequate, nothing great. Here are the problems we encountered:1. Our waiter was bsing his way through the menu saying things like "the tuna tartar is hand chopped" what else would it be? Bought prepackaged? He made a comment on how we didnt order the popular french fries, received fries anyway, then realized that they gave fries for free to everyone. He was trying to run up the bill. I asked him why our tuna tartar appetizer was $38 and he said that "since we were sharing it he took the liberty of making it a double portion so that everyone would be happy." I'm serious, he really said that. Anyway, you get the picture with the waiter. The other servers were good.2. The restaurant's "temporary" space is shared with a nightclub. The main doors were constantly open (during 5 degree weather) making it extremely cold in the dining room. The bathrooms are graffiti filled and disgusting. As people were leaving around us the staff would take their tables away to prepare for the transition into a nightclub. They were literally moving furniture around right next to our table. Promoters were coming in and out of the dining room to discuss problems with the manager. We asked for our coats during dinner because our dates were freezing and no one got the hint. On our way out, the place was mobbed with teens waiting on line to enter the "foam party". 3. During dinner I received an email from opentable.com stating that the restaurant's management had cancelled my reservation. LoL4. Four people, $70 bottle of wine, $600. For that money you can eat at 3 Michelin star restaurants and Queue de Cheval in no way lives up to those.Try rib and reef instead.

The food was very good, but not exceptional.  The service was VERY attentive, but the constant up-sell on both food and wine was a bit irritating.  The décor was perhaps the high point; as a large group we were seated downstairs and everyone loved the bar/sea-food counter and wine-barrel ceiling.  This place does have one interesting quirk - after you order, they show you the raw meat and (if ordered) live seafood, before cooking it.  I and some others enjoyed the experience, but others were a bit put off by the wriggling lobster.

We went out to the Q last night, at it's temporary lodging of 1234 (pronounced twelve thirty-four), ready to eat slabs of beef and be manly men. Their tables were set up predominately outside the club, but we were seated at one of the two interior tables by a gorgeous hostess. We joked "let the night begin!"Let me get all talk of the "view" out of the way. This place was swarming with beautiful ladies, of a variety of ages. They walked in from outside, or came down from the upstairs bar area, chatting and always smiling. Quite a sight for any hotblooded male, and certainly boosted the energy of the night for us.Our waiter came by after we had been seated, Jackie was his name, and gave us the regular steakhouse spiel. He showed off the cuts, and informed us on how the meats are aged and yadda yadda. I have to say, this guy proved to be the defining feature of the Q experience and we received some of the best service we've ever had from this guy. He informed us early on, "I want you guys to feel at home here; This is your table. I'm gonna have guys buzzing around all night for whatever you want", and he delivered. The atmosphere was relaxed, and we all felt comfortable sitting there. Wine and water was refilled as soon as the glass was nearing empty, and we were never rushed to move onto the next course.On Waiter Jackie's recommendation, we ordered several sides for table to share and most of us got Kansas bone-in steaks. I also ordered a salmon tartar and a prosciutto & burrata plate as an entree. I should mention that I'm not a big beef eater, and so I wasn't afraid to chow down on the alternatives. For sides we got the lobster and truffle mashed potatoes, garlic mashed potatoes, a mac & cheese, and garlic sauteed spinach.The tartar was great, and I would definitely recommend you try it. It was nice and bright pink, served with a little tiny dollop of cream and a sprinkle of roe. A very refreshing little dish to wake up your tongue. The prosciutto & burrata plate was also a great choice. I was wary at first, I had never had burrata before and, having had (amazing) homemade proscuitto, had little faith in restaurant cured meats. However, I was pleasantly surprised with it. The meat was all around nice, though cut a little thick I think, and the cheese had a nice taste and consistency. Our main courses arrived, and we all dug in, having smelt the food coming all the way from the kitchen. These are some big ass steaks. Like, really thick. And big. Taste-wise, they tasted like your average steaks, nothing special and no one at the table had any serious foodgasms over the meat. A warning: our chef seemed to be on a medium-rare streak, and cooked all the steaks as such, irrelevant of how they were requested. A little disappointing. I recommend getting a sauce or butter for the steak; One at the table ordered a Cajun butter, and he looked very pleased.As for the sides, the lobster mash was a little bit of a miss for me. The lobster element was actually chunks of lobster and so it took me 2 spoonfuls of the stuff to actually get any lobster taste, and my third and fourth was lacking in lobster as well. The mac & cheese was much better, just creamy enough and with a deliciously melty top layer of cheese. Several at the table commented that the cheese used was too strong; I didn't feel that was the case. I did not try the spinach or garlic mash.We skipped desert, and split the bill (note that they do not take debit cards but do have an ATM. It has a withdrawal limit of 100$, so plan accordingly.); It came to about 100-150$ per person, which is decent. Big portions + well known place = $$$$TL;DR Go for the entrees and the women, stay for the great service; get a sauce or butter for your steak, or skip the steak for something from the seafood menu (if you dare. Jackie won't be happy).

Directly in front of our hotel, Novotel, we decided to give this place a try. I regret to say we had a horrible experience! Our experience turned sour when we started hearing some yelling. We weren't sure what was going on at first. It turned into some more extremely loud yelling/swearing. When we inquired from our waiter what was going on, he let us know that the person yelling was the owner. This was appalling and disturbing to know the 'owner' was doing this in front of all the customers currently dining in. Our waiter was whispering to us and trying to assure us things were okay- they clearly were not as the owner continued to belittle and yell at his waiters/cooks/employees. To one specifically employee- he called a 'crippled'. We got to taste the wedge salad and the fries- those were actually tasty, but unfortunately it was very hard to try and enjoy the food with the hostile atmosphere the owner was creating. We decided to get up in the middle of his continuous yelling/swearing towards his employees and asked for our check. We refused to wait for the rest of our meal. This was such a horrible experience- I was in tears in the restaurant. Why somebody thinks it's okay to belittle and treat others in such a manner is beyond me. Even if you're wealthy and powerful- it is NOT okay!!! I will add that they didn't charge us for the salad, fries and water even though we insisted on paying. I left there guilty that I didn't say anything to the owner about his behavior. I really hope our waiter didn't get stuck paying for our meal either. When we went to grab dessert later during the day, the owner of the establishment asked us if we had tried out the Queue de Cheval Steakhouse as he had recommended it for good food. We told him about our experience and he stated "ohhh yeah, if the owner was there it was probably a bad experience- numerous people have experienced the same. I'm sorry and it's a shame because they do have good food".  That's pretty disappointing that other business owners know this about this as well. I recommend the Owner take some anger management classes. If the employees messed up in some way with preparing or serving food- this is still NO way to address them and to do it in front of paying customers is NOT acceptable.
Top notch above and beyond. First class food awesome, drinks delightful service a+++. This os what i'm talking about

I walked by many times and looked at the aging meat at the corner window and never came in.  Finally I decided to try it on this last trip.The place is really the in place to go for a steak in Montreal.  We had a half dozen oysters, steaks, sides, a bottle of wine shared a dessert and it all came to $330 or so with tip.  So it was expensive.Curious that there are no soup on the menu.  My medium rare fillet was a bit tough to cut.  It was pretty thick.  The mushrooms are really nice.  We had a bottle of Barbera d'Alba that cost $7o, one of of a few choices below $100.  The chocolate cakes at the end was nice.  The table close to the kitchen was a vantage point to see the cooks tending the grill, hostess seating tables, waiters working the tables.  All in all not a bad experience.p.s. Manager Adam C. sent a message after the review.  That's a man watching over his operation.

This place is a huge rip off, read the other negative reviews, they are spot on.  It is a steakhouse, but they were "out" of the lesser expensive steaks, but encouraged us strongly to look at the most expensive steaks as an alternative.  The wine list prices wine at 4-5X retail, and if you order something in the $175 (Canadian) price range (which will be extremely hard to find on their list, most are $275-500), they say they are also "out of that selection", then offer a much lesser priced selection "at the same price".  Downstairs dining room is really just a sports bar, with 3 big screen TV's, a few booths and maybe 10-12 tables, but loud.  Not elegant as their pictures show.  To give an example of the wine list, a $78 retail (Canadian) bottle of Silver Oak 2013 cabernet was priced at $575 Canadian.  You get the picture.  Most restaurants mark up the wine 2.5-3 times THEIR cost (not retail), but this place........  Would never go back.

Worst restaurant experience. I should have read the other reviews that are consistent with our experience. We arrived at 9:04 for a 9pm reservation, I say this because I see the manager blaming guests for being late when it's not true. Asked for bread three times and it came out after bread plates were taken. Steaks undercooked after being sent back twice, manager Donato had a demeaning tone. All of the food came out cold. I asked the manager to try it to see how cold it is and he said he didn't disagree with me, then at the end of the night changed his stance and said they were hot. They ruined my friends shirt and pants by spilling the steak juice on him while carrying the plate over his head. They were proud that they did us a favor by removing the two sides that they never brought out. They did nothing else to remedy the situation. Claimed that they were watching each of us and we finished our steaks, which none of us did. We came to have a good meal, but unfortunately that was not the case. For anyone reading this read management's condescending response to bad reviews, that's exactly what you'll experience when you're there.
Ok, let's be serious, it is THE place to eat in Montréal !Great food, ambiance and Fun.

Very attentive and helpful staff across the board.  Hostess, waitress, bartender were all great. The food was mediocre. You really go more for the broad experience than the food.  Not that the food was bad. But I definitely wouldn't be going back if I really wanted a great steak. It's just ok.

A bit overpriced, but the service is excellent and the food very good. We went a bit overboard when we ordered and walked out with leftovers (I should say, my partner went overboard while I looked on in shock). I won't list what we ate because it offends even me, but it involved a range of menu items and so I say with some certainty that you can pick whatever you want and it'll be good. However, it is a bit disappointing that it's billed as a steakhouse and the steak isn't the best you've ever had in your life (the oysters, on the other hand, were fabulous).It is a bit dark in the restaurant, giving it a very intimate atmosphere. I wouldn't come here with a huge boisterous group, but this is definitely a good date spot. My favorite part was when the sommelier came by, told us he didn't have the bottle we had ordered, and gave us a different (more expensive) bottle for the same price as the one we had ordered. Service in Montreal? I had thought this was a thing of fantasy, but obviously something has changed in the last few years.

QDC has been one of my absolute favourite restaurants almost 10 years now. My most recent visit has led me to write a review letting those who are either not familiar with this special place but even for those who do that QDC remains one of kind to its fullest.My recent visit was on Dec. 4 for my 35th birthday! i was accompanied by my husband, 2 year old daughter, in-laws and my mom who were blows away buy the service, staff, food and ambience. In a nutshell my mother kept asking me, " what have we done to get this incredible service as if we are special"? the truth is, Peter Morenztos and his staff treat every customer as if they are famous!
